message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the behavior of water when it freezes. When water freezes, it expands and takes up more space than it did in its liquid form. However, this expansion is accounted for by the balloon, meaning that the same amount of water is contained within the balloon even when it is frozen. Option (A) is incorrect because the amount of water does not decrease. Option (B) is unrelated to the freezing of water. Option (D) is incorrect because the expansion of water when it freezes means that there is not a greater amount of water.

This question requires an understanding of the properties of water and how it behaves when it freezes. When a water balloon is frozen, the water inside will still remain the same amount. Water expands when it freezes, so it will take up more space and cause the balloon to expand. However, once the water is completely frozen, it will still contain the same amount of water as it did when it was in a liquid state. Option (A) is incorrect because freezing the water does not decrease the amount of water. Option (B) is incorrect because the water will not turn into frozen ice-cream. Option (D) is incorrect because freezing the water does not increase the amount of water.

This question requires knowledge about the behavior of water when it freezes. When water freezes and turns into ice, it expands in volume. However, since the water balloon is already filled to its maximum capacity with water, it cannot expand any further. Therefore, the frozen water balloon will still contain the same amount of water as before it was frozen. Option (A) is incorrect because freezing does not remove or reduce the amount of water. Option (B) is incorrect because freezing does not turn water into ice cream. Option (D) is incorrect because freezing actually causes the water to expand in volume, not increase in quantity.
